title: Severed Octopus Arms Can Live On Their Own For A REALLY LONG TIME And I'm Freaking Out
text: Reactiongifs.com ID: 10577747 7. UH YEAH. According to Katherine Harmon, who’s writing a book on octopi, their “arms can continue reacting to stimuli even after they are no longer connected to the main brain” FOR UP TO AN HOUR. View this image › Zhengzaishuru / Getty Images According to Harmon, who wrote about the wonders of octopi for Scientific American, the ability of the detached tentacle to continue to respond to stimuli could be a sign that octopi have “nociceptors,” which are “neurons that are dedicated to sensing physical danger.” ID: 10578112 8. So in other words, octopus tentacles can continue to flex, move, and respond to the world around them, even when they’re detached from an octopus brain because they FEEL FEAR. Jung Yeon-je / AFP / Getty Images ID: 10578111 9. Als octopus severed limbs will attempt to grab food and bring it to their phantom mouths as a REFLEX.
